qas.question: When did binding precedent become possible in the United States?
What made binding precedent a possibility?

answers.text: creation of a clear court hierarchy (under the Judiciary Acts), and the beginning of regular verbatim publication of U.S. appellate decisions by West Publishing

qas.question: What can invalidate the rule of law?
Why was the rule of precedent allowed?

answers.text: in the absence of case law, it would be completely unworkable for every minor issue in every legal case to be briefed, argued, and decided

qas.question: How is a court hierarchy established?
What company published the Judiciary Acts?
What public policy has been ruled as an undermining of the rule of law?
What is the name of the writer of the rule of binding precedent?

context: In turn, according to <b9_0>Kozinski<b9_0/>'s analysis, the contemporary rule of <b5_0>binding precedent<b5_0/> became possible in the U.S. in <b6_0>the <a0_0>nineteenth century<b6_0/><a0_0/> only after the <a1_0>creation of a clear court hierarchy (under <a4_0>the Judiciary Acts<a4_0/>), and the beginning of regular verbatim publication of U.S. appellate decisions by <b7_0>West Publishing<b7_0/><a1_0/>. The rule gradually developed, case-by-case, as an extension of the judiciary's public policy of effective judicial administration (that is, in order to efficiently exercise the judicial power). The rule of <b8_0>precedent<b8_0/> is generally justified today as a matter of public policy, first, as a matter of fundamental fairness, and second, because <a3_0>in the absence of case law, it would be completely unworkable for every minor issue in every legal case to be briefed, argued, and decided<a3_0/> from first principles (such as relevant statutes, constitutional provisions, and underlying public policies), which in turn would create <a2_0>hopeless inefficiency, instability, and unpredictability<a2_0/>, and thereby undermine the rule of law.
